metadata.titleEn: ChinaHighPM10: High-resolution and High-quality Ground-level PM10 Dataset for China (2000-2023)
metadata.description:
ChinaHighPM10 is one of the series of long-term, full-coverage, high-resolution, and high-quality datasets of ground-level air pollutants for China (i.e., ChinaHighAirPollutants, CHAP). It is generated from the big data (e.g., ground-based measurements, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations) using artificial intelligence by considering the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. This is the big data-derived seamless (spatial coverage = 100%) daily, monthly, and yearly 1 km (i.e., D1K, M1K, and Y1K) ground-level PM10 dataset in China from 2000 to present. This dataset yields a high quality with a cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) of 0.90 and a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 21.12 µg m-3 on a daily basis. Note that this dataset is continuously updated, and if you want to apply for more data or have any questions, please contact me (Email: weijing_rs@163.com; weijing@umd.edu).
The data file contains four codes (Python, Matlab, IDL and R language) nc2geotiff codes for NC to GeoTiff.
metadata.instructions: File Name: The data is stored in the NetCDF file format, and the file name is CHAP_PM10_ab_yyyymmdd_V1.nc, where a represents time resolution (D represents daily data, M represents monthly data, Y represents annual data), b represents spatial resolution (1K represents 1km), yyyy represents year, mm represents month, and dd represents day. Data reading method: Python, Matlab, IDL, and other programming methods can be used to convert files from NC to TIF. The data coordinate system is WGS-1984, with a background value of 65535.

literatureList.titleEn: The ChinaHighPM10 dataset: generation, validation, and spatiotemporal variations from 2015 to 2019 across China
literatureList.referenceEn: Wei, J., Li, Z., Xue, W., Sun, L., Fan, T., Liu, L., Su, T., & Cribb, M. (2021). The ChinaHighPM10 dataset: generation, validation, and spatiotemporal variations from 2015 to 2019 across China. Environment International, 146, 106290. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envint.2020.106290

background: Respirable particles with aerodynamic diameters ≤ 10 µm (PM10) have important impacts on the atmospheric environment and human health. While PM10 mainly comes from nature, e.g., dust, soil, and sea salt, anthropogenic activities also play an important role in the emission of PM10, such as construction-generated dust, insufficient combustion of fossil fuels, and discharge of industrial residues. PM10 is thus of great concern to both the atmospheric environment and human health, given its potential contribution to cancer, respiratory diseases, and heart diseases, especially in developing countries like China. The Chinese Ministry of Environmental Protection has thus established a national ground-based monitoring network to monitor typical air pollutants (e.g., PM10, PM2.5, ozone, and sulfur dioxide) in real time. Satellite remote sensing has the advantage of providing complete and uniform coverage. A positive relationship between AOD and near-surface PM concentrations has been shown despite uncertainties due to various sources of the retrievals. At present, satellite-based PM estimation methods fall into four main categories: physical models, chemical models, statistical regression models, and artificial intelligence. Despite these efforts, further improvements can be made in estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations in China.
research objective: To overcome these limitations, we have adopted here a more accurate ensemble learning approach by integrating spatiotemporal information, resulting in a method called the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET). This method was used to establish robust PM10-AOD relationships. A high-quality PM10 dataset at a spatial resolution of 1 km covering China was finally generated from the STET model, i.e., ChinaHighPM10, using the newly released MODIS 1-km Multi-Angle Implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product, along with meteorological, land use, topography, and population data as input.
challenges: Despite these efforts, further improvements can be made in estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations in China. First, traditional physical, chemical, and statistical regression models generally have less data mining abilities than do machine learning methods. Second, most previous studies employed MODIS AOD products generated from the Dark Target (DT) or Deep Blue (DB) aerosol algorithms at spatial resolutions of 3 – 10 km. The coarse-resolution PM10 dataset generated thus has limited applications in medium- or small-scale areas such as urban regions where air pollution is much more locally concentrated than in rural regions. Last, PM10 is less intensively studied than PM2.5 in China, possibly because coarser particles have less impact on human health for the same mass concentration.
methods: For the STET model, daily PM10 ground-based measurements, AOD, along with 12 auxiliary factors, are first spatiotemporally collocated at each PM10 monitoring station in each year and are used to form the data samples. Second, a training set (n) is randomly selected from all data samples (N), and m features are randomly selected from all features (M) without replacement. Then a split (s*) is selected among all generated splits (S) according to the calculated scores (s*, S), and an extremely randomized tree is built based on the Classification And Regression Tree (CART) algorithm. Last, the above steps are repeated to construct numerous extremely randomized trees as weak classifiers, which are then combined to form a strong classifier.
dataset: The 1-km resolution Multi-Angle Implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product and auxiliary factors, including meteorology, land-use cover, surface elevation, population distribution, and pollutant emissions, are used in the STET model to generate the high-resolution (1 km) and high-quality PM10 dataset for China (i.e., ChinaHighPM10) from 2015 to 2019. PM10 near the ground has been monitored across China by China’s National Environmental Monitoring Center (CNEMC) at 1480 stations in 2015 then increased to 1605 stations in 2019.
findings: The product has an out-of-sample (out-of-station) cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) of 0.86 (0.82) and a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 24.28 (27.07) μg/m3, outperforming most widely used models from previous related studies. High levels of PM10 concentration occurred in northwest China (e.g., the Tarim Basin) and the Northern China Plain. Overall, PM10 concentrations had a significant declining trend of 5.81 μg/m3 per year (p < 0.001) over the past five years in China, especially in three key urban agglomerations. The ChinaHighPM10 dataset is potentially useful for future small- and medium-scale air pollution studies by virtue of its higher spatial resolution and overall accuracy.

Verification.Question: Does the use of artificial intelligence in data collection methods improve the estimation of near-surface PM10 concentrations?
Are satellite-based PM estimation methods limited by the spatial resolution of the aerosol products?
Is the ChinaHighPM10 dataset generated at a spatial resolution of 1 km?

Disjunctive.Question: Does the STET model used for PM10 data generation primarily involve physical models, chemical models, statistical regression models, or artificial intelligence?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main challenges in estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations in China?
Concept Completion.Answer: limited data mining abilities, coarse resolution of PM10 datasets, less intensive study of PM10

Concept Completion.Question: Where are PM10 monitoring stations located across China?
What auxiliary factors are used in the STET model to generate a high-resolution PM10 dataset?
Concept Completion.Answer: meteorology, land-use cover, surface elevation, population distribution, pollutant emissions

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations using traditional models?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations using traditional models is their limited data mining abilities compared to machine learning methods. These models often rely on coarse-resolution MODIS AOD products, which restricts their application in urban areas where air pollution is highly localized.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that combines satellite data with auxiliary factors to improve PM10 estimation accuracy?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that combines satellite data with auxiliary factors is the high-resolution ChinaHighPM10 dataset. It uses the 1-km resolution Multi-Angle Implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product along with meteorological data, land use, topography, population distribution, and pollutant emissions to enhance the accuracy of PM10 estimates.

Feature Specification.Question: What characteristics define the challenges in accurately estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations?
Feature Specification.Answer: limited data mining abilities of traditional models, use of coarse-resolution MODIS AOD products

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the PM10 dataset generated using the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model?
How many PM10 monitoring stations were there in China in 2019?
What is the root-mean-square error (RMSE) of the PM10 dataset when evaluated with out-of-sample validation?

Definition.Question: What is the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) approach in the context of estimating PM10 concentrations?
Definition.Answer: The space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) approach is an ensemble learning method that integrates spatiotemporal information to establish robust PM10-AOD relationships. It involves spatiotemporal collocation of daily PM10 ground-based measurements and auxiliary factors at PM10 monitoring stations. The method constructs numerous extremely randomized trees using the Classification And Regression Tree (CART) algorithm as weak classifiers, which are combined to form a strong classifier.

Definition.Question: What are some challenges associated with traditional models for estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations in China?
Definition.Answer: Traditional physical, chemical, and statistical regression models generally have less data mining abilities compared to machine learning methods. They often use MODIS AOD products with coarser spatial resolutions, limiting the applications for small or urban areas where air pollution is more localized. Moreover, PM10 is less intensively studied than PM2.5, possibly due to a perceived lesser impact on human health for the same mass concentration.

Definition.Question: What auxiliary data sources are utilized in generating a high-resolution PM10 dataset for China?
Definition.Answer: The high-resolution PM10 dataset is generated using the 1-km resolution Multi-Angle Implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product along with auxiliary data including meteorology, land-use cover, surface elevation, population distribution, and pollutant emissions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data sources and methodologies between ground-based monitoring networks and satellite remote sensing for PM10 emission data collection in China?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based monitoring networks in China, established by the Ministry of Environmental Protection, provide real-time data at numerous stations, whereas satellite remote sensing offers complete and uniform coverage using products like MODIS MAIAC AOD. The latter employs various models, such as statistical regression and AI, to estimate PM concentrations, integrating meteorology, land use, and other auxiliary factors.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations differ between medium- and small-scale areas when using coarse-resolution MODIS AOD products versus high-resolution datasets?
Comparison.Answer: Coarse-resolution MODIS AOD products, typically ranging from 3-10 km, are less effective for medium- or small-scale areas, such as urban regions, due to the localized nature of pollution. High-resolution datasets like the 1 km ChinaHighPM10 dataset provide more accurate estimations and are better suited for detailed studies in these regions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise in using traditional models for estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations, and how can machine learning methods address these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: Traditional physical, chemical, and statistical regression models often have limited data mining capabilities, which can result in less accurate PM10 estimates. Machine learning methods, such as the ensemble learning approach used in the STET model, can overcome these limitations by effectively integrating spatiotemporal information and leveraging high-resolution datasets, leading to improved estimation of PM10 concentrations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating near-surface PM10 concentrations in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional physical, chemical, and statistical regression models generally have less data mining abilities than machine learning methods. Additionally, previous studies have mostly used MODIS AOD products generated from the Dark Target (DT) or Deep Blue (DB) aerosol algorithms at coarser spatial resolutions of 3 – 10 km, which limits the application in urban areas where pollution is more locally concentrated. Moreover, PM10 is less intensively studied than PM2.5 in China, possibly because coarser particles have less impact on human health for the same mass concentration.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limitations in the application of satellite-based PM estimation methods in small or urban areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Satellite-based PM estimation methods often suffer from limitations due to the use of MODIS AOD products at coarser resolutions of 3 – 10 km, which are inadequate for medium- or small-scale areas like urban regions. In these areas, air pollution is much more locally concentrated than in rural regions, necessitating higher resolution data for accurate assessment and analysis.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of employing a high-resolution aerosol product like MODIS MAIAC in generating PM10 datasets for China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a high-resolution aerosol product like MODIS MAIAC allows for the generation of a high-quality PM10 dataset with a spatial resolution of 1 km, which is more suitable for small- and medium-scale air pollution studies. It enables better monitoring of PM10 concentrations, particularly in urban regions, and contributes to a declining trend in PM10 levels over time, as observed over the past five years in China.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a high-resolution dataset for PM10 concentrations using advanced AI techniques?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to create a more accurate dataset that overcomes the limitations of traditional modeling approaches by utilizing ensemble learning and spatiotemporal information, ultimately improving the estimation of near-surface PM10 concentrations across China.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the key objectives in integrating satellite data and ground-based measurements for air pollution studies in China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to leverage the complete and uniform coverage provided by satellite remote sensing and combine it with ground-based measurements to establish robust relationships between AOD and PM10, thereby generating a high-quality dataset suitable for small- and medium-scale air pollution studies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can ensemble learning approaches be applied to improve the accuracy of PM10 concentration estimates in China?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An ensemble learning approach, specifically the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model, can be applied by integrating spatiotemporal information. This method establishes robust PM10-AOD relationships by utilizing MODIS 1-km MAIAC aerosol products along with additional meteorological, land use, topography, and population data as inputs to generate a high-quality PM10 dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to validate the accuracy of high-resolution PM10 datasets generated from satellite data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The accuracy of high-resolution PM10 datasets is validated through cross-validation techniques. The dataset mentioned achieves an out-of-sample cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) of 0.86 and a root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 24.28 μg/m3, which confirms its effectiveness compared to other models in related studies. This process ensures that the dataset is reliable for future air pollution studies.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the generation of high-resolution PM10 datasets across China?
Enablement.Answer: The use of artificial intelligence techniques, including the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model, has enabled the generation of high-resolution PM10 datasets. This method integrates spatiotemporal information and utilizes the MODIS 1-km Multi-Angle Implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product, along with meteorological, land use, topography, and population data, to establish robust PM10-AOD relationships and produce high-quality datasets.

Enablement.Question: What are the conditions or challenges that necessitate the development of advanced models for PM10 estimation in China?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the limitations of traditional physical, chemical, and statistical regression models in data mining capabilities, the coarse resolution of previous PM10 datasets generated from MODIS AOD products, and the underrepresentation of PM10 studies compared to PM2.5. These challenges necessitate advanced models like the STET model to improve estimation accuracy and applicability, especially in urban areas with locally concentrated air pollution.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you find the use of artificial intelligence in enhancing the accuracy of PM10 concentration estimates in China?
Judgmental.Answer: Artificial intelligence, particularly the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model, is highly effective in enhancing the accuracy of PM10 concentration estimates. It integrates spatiotemporal information and utilizes various auxiliary data, resulting in a high-quality PM10 dataset with a CV-R2 of 0.86 and RMSE of 24.28 μg/m3, outperforming many traditional models.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what potential improvements could be made to data collection methods for PM10 to better address the limitations identified in previous studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Improvements could include leveraging advanced machine learning techniques with better data mining capabilities than traditional models, using finer resolution satellite products like the MODIS MAIAC aerosol product, and integrating diverse auxiliary datasets such as meteorology, land use, and population distribution to enhance PM10 concentration estimation.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how integrating spatiotemporal information enhances the accuracy of air pollution datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Integrating spatiotemporal information allows for a more accurate modeling of PM10-AOD relationships by considering variations in space and time, which leads to the generation of a high-quality PM10 dataset at a spatial resolution of 1 km, utilizing advanced methods such as the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the advantages of using artificial intelligence over traditional physical, chemical, and statistical regression models in estimating PM10 concentrations.
Assertion.Answer: Artificial intelligence models have greater data mining abilities compared to traditional physical, chemical, and statistical regression models, allowing for more accurate and comprehensive estimation of PM10 concentrations, as evidenced by the improved performance of the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) approach.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why the PM10 dataset has high relevance despite PM10 being less intensively studied than PM2.5 in China.
Assertion.Answer: The PM10 dataset is highly relevant due to its impact on both the atmospheric environment and human health, with concerns about PM10 contributing to cancer, respiratory diseases, and heart diseases. Moreover, the high-resolution PM10 dataset is particularly useful for small- and medium-scale air pollution studies, providing detailed insights that are crucial for understanding and managing air quality in urban areas.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used for generating a high-resolution PM10 dataset and any challenges associated with these methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection method involves using the space-time extremely randomized trees (STET) model, which integrates spatiotemporal information to establish PM10-AOD relationships. This method utilizes the MODIS 1-km Multi-Angle Implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product along with auxiliary data such as meteorological, land use, topography, and population data. Challenges include the less intensive study of PM10 compared to PM2.5 and the limited data mining ability of traditional models compared to machine learning methods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the methodological approaches used to handle spatial and temporal gaps in satellite-derived aerosol optical depth (AOD) data for PM10 estimation.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodological approach involves filling spatial gaps in the satellite-derived MODIS MAIAC AOD product using artificial intelligence techniques. Spatiotemporal collocation of daily PM10 ground-based measurements, AOD, and auxiliary factors at each PM10 monitoring station forms the basis for data samples. The STET model employs an ensemble learning approach to integrate spatiotemporal information, thereby improving the estimation of near-surface PM10 concentrations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the potential datasets and auxiliary factors that can be used to generate high-quality PM10 data for research purposes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets and auxiliary factors include the Multi-Angle Implementation of Atmospheric Correction (MAIAC) aerosol product at 1-km resolution and data on meteorology, land-use cover, surface elevation, population distribution, and pollutant emissions. These factors are used in conjunction with the STET model to produce a high-resolution and high-quality PM10 dataset for China. Ground-based monitoring data from China's National Environmental Monitoring Center is also crucial in this process.
